title: This music teacher is running the Boston Marathon for Parkinson’s research
author: Annie Jonas
bullets: Owen Hughes Jr., a music teacher from New York, will run the 2026 Boston Marathon.
Hughes is running his ninth marathon to raise funds for The Michael J. Fox Foundation for Parkinson's Research.
Hughes's father was diagnosed with Parkinson's, inspiring him to support research and honor his family.

title: Recent homes sales in Greater Boston (Feb. 18)
author: The Boston Globe
bullets: Abington property sales include a one-family Colonial at 840 Hancock St for $705,000 and a ranch at 193 Linwood St for $610,000.
Amesbury property sales feature a three-family flat at 102 Market St for $965,500, and a two-family duplex at 2 Elmwood St for $850,000.
In Arlington, a condo townhouse at 31 Mott St sold for $1,365,000, and 789 Concord Turnpike, a one-family garrison, sold for $880,000.

title: Cardi B appears to confirm Stefon Diggs split at L.A. concert
author: Carson Lyle
bullets: Cardi B indicated a breakup with Patriots receiver Stefon Diggs during her February concert in Los Angeles.
Rumors of their split arose as the pair unfollowed each other on Instagram after the Patriots' Super Bowl loss.
Stefon Diggs, facing battery charges, is due in Massachusetts court on April 1 for a pre-trial hearing.

title: UMass ordered to lift suspension for student who organized pro-Palestinian protest
author: Darin Zullo
bullets: A judge ruled that UMass Amherst violated Junior Kivlighan de Montebello's First Amendment rights by suspending him after a protest.
Montebello led a pro-Palestinian protest against RTX's presence at a campus career fair, resulting in a one-year suspension.
The court ordered UMass to lift Montebello's suspension and stop further sanctions while the lawsuit proceeds.

title: Hanover police officer charged with motor vehicle homicide in fatal Brockton hit-and-run
author: Darin Zullo
bullets: Hanover officer Thomas Hayes charged with motor vehicle homicide in fatal Brockton hit-and-run involving Alfredo Alves.
Hayes allegedly struck Alves with a 2022 Ford Explorer after leaving a Brockton strip club with friends.
Hayes, who smelled of alcohol upon arrest, pleaded not guilty and was placed on administrative leave.

title: Choosing a product that fixes foggy headlights
author: John Paul
bullets: Turtle Wax pads can make headlights look nearly new in 15 minutes but fog again within three months.
Meguiar’s ceramic coating applied after cleaning headlights prevents re-fogging for up to a year.
Fogged headlights can block up to 90% of light, prompting AAA to include cleaning in routine maintenance.

title: Man arrested in Fenway on child rape, human trafficking charges
author: Carson Lyle
bullets: Talik Rashaun Garcia, 36, arrested in Fenway on child rape and human trafficking charges after a police search.
Garcia was arraigned in Boston Municipal Court in Roxbury, pleading not guilty to all charges, and released on $5,000 cash bail.
The Massachusetts State Police High-Risk Victims Squad assisted in the investigation leading to Garcia's arrest.

title: Man charged with motor vehicle homicide in Pittsfield hit and run that saw victim dragged 4 miles, DA says
author: Carson Lyle
bullets: William Gross, 65, charged with motor vehicle homicide for a fatal hit-and-run in Pittsfield, Massachusetts.
Victim William Colbert, 69, was dragged four miles after being struck at Linden Street/Francis Avenue intersection.
Gross arrested after an investigation and faces arraignment in Central Berkshire District Court on Wednesday.

title: Mass. RMV lottery opens for 250th anniversary license plates. Here’s how to apply.
author: Autumn Sloboda
bullets: Massachusetts RMV launches a lottery for 1,000 low-number commemorative license plates for the state's 250th anniversary.
The commemorative plate design includes '1776' with 13 stars and '250 Years of Independence' inscription.
Applications are open from Feb. 16 to April 17, 2026, via RMV Online Service Center; winners pay $100 in fees.

title: Massachusetts becomes first state to use ChatGPT in the executive branch, drawing criticism
author: Annie Jonas
bullets: Massachusetts deploys ChatGPT for nearly 40,000 executive branch employees, being the first state in the US to do so.
The AI assistant by OpenAI aims to enhance government efficiency but faces criticism over job impact and pace of implementation.
State workers express security concerns while union representatives claim the AI rollout is rushed and potentially reduces job duties.
